data.name: heading
data.body: The Moving Coil Galvanometer

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The moving coil galvanometer (MCG) is a crucial instrument for measuring currents and voltages in circuits. Its principle is based on the interaction between a coil and a magnetic field.

data.name: bold
data.body: Principle

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The galvanometer consists of a coil, with many turns, free to rotate about a fixed axis in a uniform radial magnetic field. A cylindrical soft iron core enhances the strength of the magnetic field. When a current \( I \) flows through the coil, a torque \( \tau \) acts on it, given by:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \tau = NIAB \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: where \( N \) is the number of turns, \( A \) is the area of the coil, and \( B \) is the magnetic field strength.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The torque tends to rotate the coil, opposed by a counter torque provided by a spring. In equilibrium, the torque due to the magnetic field equals the restoring torque from the spring:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ k\phi = NIAB \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: where \( k \) is the torsional constant of the spring.

data.name: bold
data.body: Usage as a Detector

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The galvanometer can serve as a detector to check if a current is flowing in the circuit. Its pointer deflects based on the direction of the current.

data.name: bold
data.body: Usage as an Ammeter

data.name: paragraph
data.body: To measure current, the galvanometer must be connected in series with a shunt resistance \( r_s \) to divert most of the current away from the coil. The resistance of this arrangement is approximately \( r_s \) if the resistance of the galvanometer (\( R_G \)) is much larger than \( r_s \).

data.name: bold
data.body: Current Sensitivity

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The current sensitivity of the galvanometer, defined as the deflection per unit current, is given by:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \frac{\phi}{I} = \frac{NAB}{k} \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Usage as a Voltmeter

data.name: paragraph
data.body: To measure voltage, the galvanometer must be connected in parallel with the circuit and draw a very small current. A large resistance \( R \) is connected in series to limit the current drawn by the galvanometer.

data.name: Voltage Sensitivity
data.body: The voltage sensitivity, defined as the deflection per unit voltage, is given by:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \frac{\phi}{V} = \frac{NAB}{k} \cdot \frac{1}{R} \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Increasing the number of turns in the coil increases the current sensitivity but may not necessarily increase the voltage sensitivity, as it depends on the resistance of the galvanometer.
